name: Insufficient Control of Network Message Volume (Network Amplification)

metadata.Description: Define a clear policy for network resource allocation and consumption.

name: Insufficient Control of Network Message Volume (Network Amplification)

metadata.Description: An application must, at all times, keep track of network resources and meter their usage appropriately.

name: Insufficient Resource Pool

metadata.Description: Do not perform resource-intensive transactions for unauthenticated users and/or invalid requests.

name: Insufficient Resource Pool

metadata.Description: Consider implementing a velocity check mechanism which would detect abusive behavior.

name: Insufficient Resource Pool

metadata.Description: Consider load balancing as an option to handle heavy loads.

name: Insufficient Resource Pool

metadata.Description: Make sure that resource handles are properly closed when no longer needed.

name: Insufficient Resource Pool

name: Double Free

name: Double Free

name: Untrusted Search Path

metadata.Description: Hard-code the search path to a set of known-safe values (such as system directories), or only allow them to be specified by the administrator in a configuration file. name: Untrusted Search Path

metadata.Description: When invoking other programs, specify those programs using fully-qualified pathnames. While this is an effective approach, code that uses fully-qualified pathnames might not be portable to other systems that do not use the same pathnames. The portability can be improved by locating the full-qualified paths in a centralized, easily-modifiable location within the source code, and having the code refer to these paths.

name: Untrusted Search Path

name: Untrusted Search Path

name: Untrusted Search Path

For example, system() in C does not require a full path since the shell can take care of it, while execl() and execv() require a full path.

name: Unquoted Search Path or Element

metadata.Description:
Assume all input is malicious. Use an "accept known good" input validation strategy, i.e., use a list of acceptable inputs that strictly conform to specifications. Reject any input that does not strictly conform to specifications, or transform it into something that does.
                  When performing input validation, consider all potentially relevant properties, including length, type of input, the full range of acceptable values, missing or extra inputs, syntax, consistency across related fields, and conformance to business rules. As an example of business rule logic, "boat" may be syntactically valid because it only contains alphanumeric characters, but it is not valid if the input is only expected to contain colors such as "red" or "blue."
                  Do not rely exclusively on looking for malicious or malformed inputs.  This is likely to miss at least one undesirable input, especially if the code's environment changes. This can give attackers enough room to bypass the intended validation. However, denylists can be useful for detecting potential attacks or determining which inputs are so malformed that they should be rejected outright.

Then, these modified values would be submitted to the server.

name: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type

metadata.Description:
Run the code in a "jail" or similar sandbox environment that enforces strict boundaries between the process and the operating system. This may effectively restrict which files can be accessed in a particular directory or which commands can be executed by the software.
                  OS-level examples include the Unix chroot jail, AppArmor, and SELinux. In general, managed code may provide some protection. For example, java.io.FilePermission in the Java SecurityManager allows the software to specify restrictions on file operations.
                  This may not be a feasible solution, and it only limits the impact to the operating system; the rest of the application may still be subject to compromise.
                  Be careful to avoid CWE-243 and other weaknesses related to jails.

                  For example, certain compilers and extensions provide automatic buffer overflow detection mechanisms that are built into the compiled code. Examples include the Microsoft Visual Studio /GS flag, Fedora/Red Hat FORTIFY_SOURCE GCC flag, StackGuard, and ProPolice.

name: Deletion of Data Structure Sentinel

metadata.Description: Use OS-level preventative functionality. Not a complete solution.

name: Addition of Data Structure Sentinel

metadata.Description: Encapsulate the user from interacting with data sentinels. Validate user input to verify that sentinels are not present.

name: Addition of Data Structure Sentinel

metadata.Description: Proper error checking can reduce the risk of inadvertently introducing sentinel values into data. For example, if a parsing function fails or encounters an error, it might return a value that is the same as the sentinel.

name: Addition of Data Structure Sentinel

metadata.Description: Use an abstraction library to abstract away risky APIs. This is not a complete solution.

name: Addition of Data Structure Sentinel

metadata.Description: Use OS-level preventative functionality. This is not a complete solution.

name: Use of sizeof() on a Pointer Type

metadata.Description: Use expressions such as "sizeof(*pointer)" instead of "sizeof(pointer)", unless you intend to run sizeof() on a pointer type to gain some platform independence or if you are allocating a variable on the stack.

name: Incorrect Pointer Scaling

metadata.Description: Use a platform with high-level memory abstractions.

name: Incorrect Pointer Scaling

metadata.Description: Always use array indexing instead of direct pointer manipulation.

name: Incorrect Pointer Scaling

metadata.Description: Use technologies for preventing buffer overflows.

name: Use of Pointer Subtraction to Determine Size

metadata.Description: Save an index variable. This is the recommended solution. Rather than subtract pointers from one another, use an index variable of the same size as the pointers in question. Use this variable to "walk" from one pointer to the other and calculate the difference. Always validate this number.

name: Use of Externally-Controlled Input to Select Classes or Code ('Unsafe Reflection')

metadata.Description: Refactor your code to avoid using reflection.

name: Use of Externally-Controlled Input to Select Classes or Code ('Unsafe Reflection')

metadata.Description: Do not use user-controlled inputs to select and load classes or code.

name: Use of Externally-Controlled Input to Select Classes or Code ('Unsafe Reflection')

metadata.Description: Apply strict input validation by using allowlists or indirect selection to ensure that the user is only selecting allowable classes or code.

name: Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data (MAID)

metadata.Description: When the data is stored or transmitted through untrusted sources that could modify the data, implement integrity checks to detect unauthorized modification, or store/transmit the data in a trusted location that is free from external influence.

name: External Control of Assumed-Immutable Web Parameter

metadata.Description:
Assume all input is malicious. Use an "accept known good" input validation strategy, i.e., use a list of acceptable inputs that strictly conform to specifications. Reject any input that does not strictly conform to specifications, or transform it into something that does.
                  When performing input validation, consider all potentially relevant properties, including length, type of input, the full range of acceptable values, missing or extra inputs, syntax, consistency across related fields, and conformance to business rules. As an example of business rule logic, "boat" may be syntactically valid because it only contains alphanumeric characters, but it is not valid if the input is only expected to contain colors such as "red" or "blue."
                  Do not rely exclusively on looking for malicious or malformed inputs.  This is likely to miss at least one undesirable input, especially if the code's environment changes. This can give attackers enough room to bypass the intended validation. However, denylists can be useful for detecting potential attacks or determining which inputs are so malformed that they should be rejected outright.

name: External Control of Assumed-Immutable Web Parameter

metadata.Description: Inputs should be decoded and canonicalized to the application's current internal representation before being validated (CWE-180). Make sure that the application does not decode the same input twice (CWE-174). Such errors could be used to bypass allowlist validation schemes by introducing dangerous inputs after they have been checked.

name: PHP External Variable Modification

metadata.Description: Carefully identify which variables can be controlled or influenced by an external user, and consider adopting a naming convention to emphasize when externally modifiable variables are being used. An application should be reluctant to trust variables that have been initialized outside of its trust boundary. Ensure adequate checking is performed when relying on input from outside a trust boundary. Do not allow your application to run with register_globals enabled. If you implement a register_globals emulator, be extremely careful of variable extraction, dynamic evaluation, and similar issues, since weaknesses in your emulation could allow external variable modification to take place even without register_globals.

name: Use of Function with Inconsistent Implementations

metadata.Description: Do not accept inconsistent behavior from the API specifications when the deviant behavior increase the risk level.

name: NULL Pointer Dereference

metadata.Description: If all pointers that could have been modified are sanity-checked previous to use, nearly all NULL pointer dereferences can be prevented.

name: NULL Pointer Dereference

metadata.Description: The choice could be made to use a language that is not susceptible to these issues.

name: NULL Pointer Dereference

metadata.Description: Check the results of all functions that return a value and verify that the value is non-null before acting upon it.

name: NULL Pointer Dereference

metadata.Description: Identify all variables and data stores that receive information from external sources, and apply input validation to make sure that they are only initialized to expected values.

name: NULL Pointer Dereference

metadata.Description: Explicitly initialize all your variables and other data stores, either during declaration or just before the first usage.

name: NULL Pointer Dereference

metadata.Description: Use automated static analysis tools that target this type of weakness. Many modern techniques use data flow analysis to minimize the number of false positives. This is not a perfect solution, since 100% accuracy and coverage are not feasible.

name: Use of Obsolete Function

metadata.Description: Refer to the documentation for the obsolete function in order to determine why it is deprecated or obsolete and to learn about alternative ways to achieve the same functionality.

name: Use of Obsolete Function

metadata.Description: Consider seriously the security implications of using an obsolete function. Consider using alternate functions.

name: Missing Default Case in Switch Statement

metadata.Description: Ensure that there are no unaccounted for cases, when adjusting flow or values based on the value of a given variable. In switch statements, this can be accomplished through the use of the default label.

name: Missing Default Case in Switch Statement

metadata.Description: In the case of switch style statements, the very simple act of creating a default case can mitigate this situation, if done correctly. Often however, the default case is used simply to represent an assumed option, as opposed to working as a check for invalid input. This is poor practice and in some cases is as bad as omitting a default case entirely.

name: Signal Handler Use of a Non-reentrant Function

metadata.Description: Require languages or libraries that provide reentrant functionality, or otherwise make it easier to avoid this weakness.

name: Signal Handler Use of a Non-reentrant Function

metadata.Description: Design signal handlers to only set flags rather than perform complex functionality.

name: Signal Handler Use of a Non-reentrant Function

metadata.Description: Ensure that non-reentrant functions are not found in signal handlers.

name: Signal Handler Use of a Non-reentrant Function

metadata.Description: Use sanity checks to reduce the timing window for exploitation of race conditions. This is only a partial solution, since many attacks might fail, but other attacks still might work within the narrower window, even accidentally.

name: Assigning instead of Comparing

metadata.Description: Many IDEs and static analysis products will detect this problem.

name: Assigning instead of Comparing

metadata.Description: Place constants on the left. If one attempts to assign a constant with a variable, the compiler will produce an error.

name: Comparing instead of Assigning

metadata.Description: Many IDEs and static analysis products will detect this problem.

name: Incorrect Block Delimitation

metadata.Description: Always use explicit block delimitation and use static-analysis technologies to enforce this practice.

name: Omitted Break Statement in Switch

metadata.Description: Omitting a break statement so that one may fall through is often indistinguishable from an error, and therefore should be avoided. If you need to use fall-through capabilities, make sure that you have clearly documented this within the switch statement, and ensure that you have examined all the logical possibilities.

name: Omitted Break Statement in Switch

metadata.Description: The functionality of omitting a break statement could be clarified with an if statement. This method is much safer.

name: Comparison of Classes by Name

metadata.Description: Use class equivalency to determine type. Rather than use the class name to determine if an object is of a given type, use the getClass() method, and == operator.

name: Reliance on Package-level Scope

metadata.Description: Data should be private static and final whenever possible. This will assure that your code is protected by instantiating early, preventing access and tampering.

name: Exposure of Data Element to Wrong Session

metadata.Description: Protect the application's sessions from information leakage. Make sure that a session's data is not used or visible by other sessions.

name: Exposure of Data Element to Wrong Session

metadata.Description: Use a static analysis tool to scan the code for information leakage vulnerabilities (e.g. Singleton Member Field).

name: Exposure of Data Element to Wrong Session

metadata.Description: In a multithreading environment, storing user data in Servlet member fields introduces a data access race condition. Do not use member fields to store information in the Servlet.

name: Active Debug Code

name: Public cloneable() Method Without Final ('Object Hijack')

metadata.Description: Make the cloneable() method final.

name: Use of Inner Class Containing Sensitive Data

metadata.Description: Using sealed classes protects object-oriented encapsulation paradigms and therefore protects code from being extended in unforeseen ways.

name: Use of Inner Class Containing Sensitive Data

metadata.Description: Inner Classes do not provide security. Warning: Never reduce the security of the object from an outer class, going to an inner class. If an outer class is final or private, ensure that its inner class is private as well.

name: Critical Public Variable Without Final Modifier

metadata.Description: Declare all public fields as final when possible, especially if it is used to maintain internal state of an Applet or of classes used by an Applet. If a field must be public, then perform all appropriate sanity checks before accessing the field from your code.

name: Download of Code Without Integrity Check

metadata.Description: Perform proper forward and reverse DNS lookups to detect DNS spoofing.

name: Download of Code Without Integrity Check

metadata.Description:
Encrypt the code with a reliable encryption scheme before transmitting.
                  This will only be a partial solution, since it will not detect DNS spoofing and it will not prevent your code from being modified on the hosting site.

name: Download of Code Without Integrity Check

metadata.Description:
Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.
                  Speficially, it may be helpful to use tools or frameworks to perform integrity checking on the transmitted code.
                  
                     
                        When providing the code that is to be downloaded, such as for automatic updates of the software, then use cryptographic signatures for the code and modify the download clients to verify the signatures. Ensure that the implementation does not contain CWE-295, CWE-320, CWE-347, and related weaknesses.
                        Use code signing technologies such as Authenticode. See references [REF-454] [REF-455] [REF-456].

name: Download of Code Without Integrity Check

metadata.Description: Run your code using the lowest privileges that are required to accomplish the necessary tasks [REF-76]. If possible, create isolated accounts with limited privileges that are only used for a single task. That way, a successful attack will not immediately give the attacker access to the rest of the software or its environment. For example, database applications rarely need to run as the database administrator, especially in day-to-day operations.

name: Download of Code Without Integrity Check

metadata.Description:
Run the code in a "jail" or similar sandbox environment that enforces strict boundaries between the process and the operating system. This may effectively restrict which files can be accessed in a particular directory or which commands can be executed by the software.
                  OS-level examples include the Unix chroot jail, AppArmor, and SELinux. In general, managed code may provide some protection. For example, java.io.FilePermission in the Java SecurityManager allows the software to specify restrictions on file operations.
                  This may not be a feasible solution, and it only limits the impact to the operating system; the rest of the application may still be subject to compromise.
                  Be careful to avoid CWE-243 and other weaknesses related to jails.

name: Serializable Class Containing Sensitive Data

name: Deserialization of Untrusted Data

metadata.Description: If available, use the signing/sealing features of the programming language to assure that deserialized data has not been tainted. For example, a hash-based message authentication code (HMAC) could be used to ensure that data has not been modified.

name: Deserialization of Untrusted Data

name: Deserialization of Untrusted Data

name: Deserialization of Untrusted Data

metadata.Description:
Make fields transient to protect them from deserialization.
                  An attempt to serialize and then deserialize a class containing transient fields will result in NULLs where the transient data should be. This is an excellent way to prevent time, environment-based, or sensitive variables from being carried over and used improperly.

name: Deserialization of Untrusted Data

This limits the potential for unintended or unauthorized types and gadgets to be leveraged by the attacker. Add only acceptable classes to an allowlist. Note: new gadgets are constantly being discovered, so this alone is not a sufficient mitigation.

This may require a detailed review of all code, as it is possible to hide a serious attack in only one or two lines of code. These lines may be located almost anywhere in an application and may have been intentionally obfuscated by the attacker.

name: Weak Password Requirements

metadata.Description:
A product's design should require adherance to an appropriate password policy. Specific password requirements depend strongly on contextual factors, but it is recommended to contain the following attributes:
                
                 
                   Enforcement of a minimum and maximum length
                   Restrictions against password reuse
                   Restrictions against using common passwords
                   Restrictions against using contextual string in the password (e.g., user id, app name)
                 
                 Depending on the threat model, the password policy may include several additional attributes.
                 
                   Complex passwords requiring mixed character sets (alpha, numeric, special, mixed case)
                     
                       Increasing the range of characters makes the password harder to crack and may be appropriate for systems relying on single factor authentication.
                       Unfortunately, a complex password may be difficult to memorize, encouraging a user to select a short password or to incorrectly manage the password (write it down).
                       Another disadvantage of this approach is that it often does not result in a significant increases in overal password complexity due to people's predictable usage of various symbols.
                     
                   
                   Large Minimum Length (encouraging passphrases instead of passwords)
                     
                       Increasing the number of characters makes the password harder to crack and may be appropriate for systems relying on single factor authentication.
                       A disadvantage of this approach is that selecting a good passphrase is not easy and poor passwords can still be generated. Some prompting may be needed to encourage long un-predictable passwords.
                     
                   
                   Randomly Chosen Secrets
                     
                       Generating a password for the user can help make sure that length and complexity requirements are met, and can result in secure passwords being used.
                       A disadvantage of this approach is that the resulting password or passpharse may be too difficult to memorize, encouraging them to be written down.
                     
                   
                   Password Expiration
                     
                       Requiring a periodic password change can reduce the time window that an adversary has to crack a password, while also limiting the damage caused by password exposures at other locations.
					   Password expiration may be a good mitigating technique when long complex passwords are not desired.
                     
                   
                 
                 
                  See NIST 800-63B https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-63b.pdf Sections: 5.1.1, 10.2.1, and Appendix A for further information on password requirements.

name: Weak Password Requirements

metadata.Description:
Consider a second
                 authentication factor beyond the password, which prevents the
                 password from being a single point of failure. See CWE-308 for
                 further information.

name: Weak Password Requirements

metadata.Description: Consider implementing a password complexity meter to inform users when a chosen password meets the required attributes.

name: Unprotected Transport of Credentials

metadata.Description: Enforce SSL use for the login page or any page used to transmit user credentials or other sensitive information. Even if the entire site does not use SSL, it MUST use SSL for login. Additionally, to help prevent phishing attacks, make sure that SSL serves the login page. SSL allows the user to verify the identity of the server to which they are connecting. If the SSL serves login page, the user can be certain they are talking to the proper end system. A phishing attack would typically redirect a user to a site that does not have a valid trusted server certificate issued from an authorized supplier.

This pattern may be used to avoid the overhead of a synchronized call, but in certain versions of Java (for example), this has been shown to be unsafe because it still introduces a race condition (CWE-209).

name: Missing Standardized Error Handling Mechanism

Use or create built-in language features, or an external package, that provides an easy-to-use API and define coding standards for the detection and handling of errors.

name: Suspicious Comment

name: Use of Hard-coded, Security-relevant Constants

name: Exposure of Information Through Directory Listing

name: Server-generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information

metadata.Description: Recommendations include designing and adding consistent error handling mechanisms which are capable of handling any user input to your web application, providing meaningful detail to end-users, and preventing error messages that might provide information useful to an attacker from being displayed.

name: Incorrect Behavior Order: Authorization Before Parsing and Canonicalization

name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Not Using Input Validation Framework

Use the ASP.NET validation framework to check all program input before it is processed by the application. Example uses of the validation framework include checking to ensure that:

name: SQL Injection: Hibernate

metadata.Description: Follow the principle of least privilege when creating user accounts to a SQL database. Users should only have the minimum privileges necessary to use their account. If the requirements of the system indicate that a user can read and modify their own data, then limit their privileges so they cannot read/write others' data.

name: SQL Injection: Hibernate

metadata.Description: For any security checks that are performed on the client side, ensure that these checks are duplicated on the server side, in order to avoid CWE-602. Attackers can bypass the client-side checks by modifying values after the checks have been performed, or by changing the client to remove the client-side checks entirely. Then, these modified values would be submitted to the server.

name: SQL Injection: Hibernate

metadata.Description: Implement SQL strings using prepared statements that bind variables. Prepared statements that do not bind variables can be vulnerable to attack.

name: SQL Injection: Hibernate

metadata.Description: Use vigorous allowlist style checking on any user input that may be used in a SQL command. Rather than escape meta-characters, it is safest to disallow them entirely. Reason: Later use of data that have been entered in the database may neglect to escape meta-characters before use. Narrowly define the set of safe characters based on the expected value of the parameter in the request.

name: Reliance on Cookies without Validation and Integrity Checking

name: Reliance on Cookies without Validation and Integrity Checking

metadata.Description: Protect critical cookies from replay attacks, since cross-site scripting or other attacks may allow attackers to steal a strongly-encrypted cookie that also passes integrity checks. This mitigation applies to cookies that should only be valid during a single transaction or session. By enforcing timeouts, you may limit the scope of an attack. As part of your integrity check, use an unpredictable, server-side value that is not exposed to the client.

name: J2EE Bad Practices: Non-serializable Object Stored in Session

metadata.Description: In order for session replication to work, the values the application stores as attributes in the session must implement the Serializable interface.

name: clone() Method Without super.clone()

metadata.Description: Call super.clone() within your clone() method, when obtaining a new object.

name: clone() Method Without super.clone()

metadata.Description: In some cases, you can eliminate the clone method altogether and use copy constructors.

name: Object Model Violation: Just One of Equals and Hashcode Defined

metadata.Description: Both Equals() and Hashcode() should be defined.

name: Array Declared Public, Final, and Static

metadata.Description: In most situations the array should be made private.

name: finalize() Method Declared Public

metadata.Description: If you are using finalize() as it was designed, there is no reason to declare finalize() with anything other than protected access.

name: Return Inside Finally Block

metadata.Description: Do not use a return statement inside the finally block. The finally block should have "cleanup" code.

name: Empty Synchronized Block

metadata.Description: When you come across an empty synchronized statement, or a synchronized statement in which the code has been commented out, try to determine what the original intentions were and whether or not the synchronized block is still necessary.

name: Explicit Call to Finalize()

metadata.Description: Do not make explicit calls to finalize(). Use static analysis tools to spot such instances.

name: Assignment of a Fixed Address to a Pointer

metadata.Description: Never set a pointer to a fixed address.

name: Attempt to Access Child of a Non-structure Pointer

metadata.Description: The choice could be made to use a language that is not susceptible to these issues.

name: Attempt to Access Child of a Non-structure Pointer

metadata.Description: Review of type casting operations can identify locations where incompatible types are cast.

name: Call to Non-ubiquitous API

metadata.Description: Always test your code on any platform on which it is targeted to run on.

name: Call to Non-ubiquitous API

metadata.Description: Test your code on the newest and oldest platform on which it is targeted to run on.

name: Call to Non-ubiquitous API

metadata.Description: Develop a system to test for API functions that are not portable.

name: Free of Memory not on the Heap

metadata.Description: Only free pointers that you have called malloc on previously. This is the recommended solution. Keep track of which pointers point at the beginning of valid chunks and free them only once.

name: Free of Memory not on the Heap

metadata.Description: Before freeing a pointer, the programmer should make sure that the pointer was previously allocated on the heap and that the memory belongs to the programmer. Freeing an unallocated pointer will cause undefined behavior in the program.

name: Free of Memory not on the Heap

metadata.Description:
Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.
                  For example, glibc in Linux provides protection against free of invalid pointers.

name: Free of Memory not on the Heap

metadata.Description: Use a language that provides abstractions for memory allocation and deallocation.

name: Free of Memory not on the Heap

metadata.Description: Use a tool that dynamically detects memory management problems, such as valgrind.

name: Sensitive Data Storage in Improperly Locked Memory

metadata.Description: Identify data that needs to be protected from swapping and choose platform-appropriate protection mechanisms.

name: Sensitive Data Storage in Improperly Locked Memory

metadata.Description: Check return values to ensure locking operations are successful.

name: Authentication Bypass: OpenSSL CTX Object Modified after SSL Objects are Created

metadata.Description: Use a language or a library that provides a cryptography framework at a higher level of abstraction.

name: Authentication Bypass: OpenSSL CTX Object Modified after SSL Objects are Created

metadata.Description: Most SSL_CTX functions have SSL counterparts that act on SSL-type objects.

name: Authentication Bypass: OpenSSL CTX Object Modified after SSL Objects are Created

metadata.Description: Applications should set up an SSL_CTX completely, before creating SSL objects from it.

name: J2EE Framework: Saving Unserializable Objects to Disk

metadata.Description: All objects that become part of session and application scope must implement the java.io.Serializable interface to ensure serializability of containing objects.

name: Comparison of Object References Instead of Object Contents

metadata.Description: In Java, use the equals() method to compare objects instead of the == operator. If using ==, it is important for performance reasons that your objects are created by a static factory, not by a constructor.

name: Use of Wrong Operator in String Comparison

metadata.Description:
Within Java, use .equals() to compare string values.
               Within JavaScript, use == to compare string values.
               Within PHP, use == to compare a numeric value to a string value. (PHP converts the string to a number.)

name: Use of GET Request Method With Sensitive Query Strings

metadata.Description: When sensitive information is sent, use the POST method (e.g. registration form).

name: Missing Validation of OpenSSL Certificate

metadata.Description: Ensure that proper authentication is included in the system design.

name: Missing Validation of OpenSSL Certificate

metadata.Description: Understand and properly implement all checks necessary to ensure the identity of entities involved in encrypted communications.

name: Uncaught Exception in Servlet

metadata.Description: Implement Exception blocks to handle all types of Exceptions.

name: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect')

metadata.Description:
Assume all input is malicious. Use an "accept known good" input validation strategy, i.e., use a list of acceptable inputs that strictly conform to specifications. Reject any input that does not strictly conform to specifications, or transform it into something that does.
                  When performing input validation, consider all potentially relevant properties, including length, type of input, the full range of acceptable values, missing or extra inputs, syntax, consistency across related fields, and conformance to business rules. As an example of business rule logic, "boat" may be syntactically valid because it only contains alphanumeric characters, but it is not valid if the input is only expected to contain colors such as "red" or "blue."
                  Do not rely exclusively on looking for malicious or malformed inputs.  This is likely to miss at least one undesirable input, especially if the code's environment changes. This can give attackers enough room to bypass the intended validation. However, denylists can be useful for detecting potential attacks or determining which inputs are so malformed that they should be rejected outright.
                  Use a list of approved URLs or domains to be used for redirection.

name: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect')

metadata.Description: Use an intermediate disclaimer page that provides the user with a clear warning that they are leaving the current site. Implement a long timeout before the redirect occurs, or force the user to click on the link. Be careful to avoid XSS problems (CWE-79) when generating the disclaimer page.

name: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect')

metadata.Description:
When the set of acceptable objects, such as filenames or URLs, is limited or known, create a mapping from a set of fixed input values (such as numeric IDs) to the actual filenames or URLs, and reject all other inputs.
                  For example, ID 1 could map to "/login.asp" and ID 2 could map to "http://www.example.com/". Features such as the ESAPI AccessReferenceMap [REF-45] provide this capability.

name: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect')

metadata.Description: Ensure that no externally-supplied requests are honored by requiring that all redirect requests include a unique nonce generated by the application [REF-483]. Be sure that the nonce is not predictable (CWE-330).

name: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect')

metadata.Description:
Understand all the potential areas where untrusted inputs can enter your software: parameters or arguments, cookies, anything read from the network, environment variables, reverse DNS lookups, query results, request headers, URL components, e-mail, files, filenames, databases, and any external systems that provide data to the application. Remember that such inputs may be obtained indirectly through API calls.
                  Many open redirect problems occur because the programmer assumed that certain inputs could not be modified, such as cookies and hidden form fields.

name: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect')

metadata.Description: Use an application firewall that can detect attacks against this weakness. It can be beneficial in cases in which the code cannot be fixed (because it is controlled by a third party), as an emergency prevention measure while more comprehensive software assurance measures are applied, or to provide defense in depth.

name: Client-Side Enforcement of Server-Side Security

metadata.Description:
For any security checks that are performed on the client side, ensure that these checks are duplicated on the server side. Attackers can bypass the client-side checks by modifying values after the checks have been performed, or by changing the client to remove the client-side checks entirely. Then, these modified values would be submitted to the server.
                  Even though client-side checks provide minimal benefits with respect to server-side security, they are still useful. First, they can support intrusion detection. If the server receives input that should have been rejected by the client, then it may be an indication of an attack. Second, client-side error-checking can provide helpful feedback to the user about the expectations for valid input. Third, there may be a reduction in server-side processing time for accidental input errors, although this is typically a small savings.

name: Client-Side Enforcement of Server-Side Security

metadata.Description: If some degree of trust is required between the two entities, then use integrity checking and strong authentication to ensure that the inputs are coming from a trusted source. Design the product so that this trust is managed in a centralized fashion, especially if there are complex or numerous communication channels, in order to reduce the risks that the implementer will mistakenly omit a check in a single code path.

name: Client-Side Enforcement of Server-Side Security

metadata.Description: Use dynamic tools and techniques that interact with the software using large test suites with many diverse inputs, such as fuzz testing (fuzzing), robustness testing, and fault injection. The software's operation may slow down, but it should not become unstable, crash, or generate incorrect results.

name: Client-Side Enforcement of Server-Side Security

metadata.Description: Use tools and techniques that require manual (human) analysis, such as penetration testing, threat modeling, and interactive tools that allow the tester to record and modify an active session. These may be more effective than strictly automated techniques. This is especially the case with weaknesses that are related to design and business rules.

name: Use of Client-Side Authentication

metadata.Description: Do not rely on client side data. Always perform server side authentication.

name: Multiple Binds to the Same Port

metadata.Description: Restrict server socket address to known local addresses.

name: Unchecked Input for Loop Condition

metadata.Description: Do not use user-controlled data for loop conditions.

name: Unchecked Input for Loop Condition

metadata.Description: Perform input validation.

name: Public Static Final Field References Mutable Object

metadata.Description: Protect mutable objects by making them private. Restrict access to the getter and setter as well.

name: Struts: Non-private Field in ActionForm Class

metadata.Description: Make all fields private. Use getter to get the value of the field. Setter should be used only by the framework; setting an action form field from other actions is bad practice and should be avoided.

name: Double-Checked Locking

metadata.Description: While double-checked locking can be achieved in some languages, it is inherently flawed in Java before 1.5, and cannot be achieved without compromising platform independence. Before Java 1.5, only use of the synchronized keyword is known to work. Beginning in Java 1.5, use of the "volatile" keyword allows double-checked locking to work successfully, although there is some debate as to whether it achieves sufficient performance gains. See references.

name: Improper Restriction of XML External Entity Reference

metadata.Description: Many XML parsers and validators can be configured to disable external entity expansion.

name: Insufficient Session Expiration

metadata.Description: Set sessions/credentials expiration date.

name: Sensitive Cookie in HTTPS Session Without 'Secure' Attribute

metadata.Description: Always set the secure attribute when the cookie should sent via HTTPS only.

name: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Comments

metadata.Description: Remove comments which have sensitive information about the design/implementation of the application. Some of the comments may be exposed to the user and affect the security posture of the application.

name: Incomplete Identification of Uploaded File Variables (PHP)

metadata.Description: Use PHP 4 or later.

name: Incomplete Identification of Uploaded File Variables (PHP)

metadata.Description: If you must support older PHP versions, write your own version of is_uploaded_file() and run it against $HTTP_POST_FILES['userfile']))

name: Incomplete Identification of Uploaded File Variables (PHP)

metadata.Description: For later PHP versions, reference uploaded files using the $HTTP_POST_FILES or $_FILES variables, and use is_uploaded_file() or move_uploaded_file() to ensure that you are dealing with an uploaded file.

name: Reachable Assertion

metadata.Description: Make sensitive open/close operation non reachable by directly user-controlled data (e.g. open/close resources)

name: Reachable Assertion

metadata.Description: Perform input validation on user data.

name: Exposed Unsafe ActiveX Method

metadata.Description: If you must expose a method, make sure to perform input validation on all arguments, and protect against all possible vulnerabilities.

name: Exposed Unsafe ActiveX Method

metadata.Description: Use code signing, although this does not protect against any weaknesses that are already in the control.

name: Exposed Unsafe ActiveX Method

metadata.Description: Where possible, avoid marking the control as safe for scripting.

name: Dangling Database Cursor ('Cursor Injection')

metadata.Description: Close cursors immediately after access to them is complete. Ensure that you close cursors if exceptions occur.

name: Unverified Password Change

metadata.Description: When prompting for a password change, force the user to provide the original password in addition to the new password.

name: Unverified Password Change

metadata.Description: Do not use "forgotten password" functionality. But if you must, ensure that you are only providing information to the actual user, e.g. by using an email address or challenge question that the legitimate user already provided in the past; do not allow the current user to change this identity information until the correct password has been provided.

name: Variable Extraction Error

metadata.Description: Use allowlists of variable names that can be extracted.

name: Variable Extraction Error

metadata.Description: Consider refactoring your code to avoid extraction routines altogether.

name: Variable Extraction Error

metadata.Description: In PHP, call extract() with options such as EXTR_SKIP and EXTR_PREFIX_ALL; call import_request_variables() with a prefix argument. Note that these capabilities are not present in all PHP versions.

name: Improper Validation of Function Hook Arguments

metadata.Description: Ensure that all arguments are verified, as defined by the API you are protecting.

name: Improper Validation of Function Hook Arguments

metadata.Description: Drop privileges before invoking such functions, if possible.

name: Unsafe ActiveX Control Marked Safe For Scripting

metadata.Description: During development, do not mark it as safe for scripting.

name: Unsafe ActiveX Control Marked Safe For Scripting

metadata.Description: After distribution, you can set the kill bit for the control so that it is not accessible from Internet Explorer.

name: Executable Regular Expression Error

metadata.Description: The regular expression feature in some languages allows inputs to be quoted or escaped before insertion, such as \Q and \E in Perl.

name: Permissive Regular Expression

metadata.Description: When applicable, ensure that the regular expression marks beginning and ending string patterns, such as "/^string$/" for Perl.

name: Null Byte Interaction Error (Poison Null Byte)

metadata.Description: Remove null bytes from all incoming strings.

name: Dynamic Variable Evaluation

metadata.Description: Refactor the code to avoid dynamic variable evaluation whenever possible.

name: Dynamic Variable Evaluation

metadata.Description: Use only allowlists of acceptable variable or function names.

name: Dynamic Variable Evaluation

metadata.Description: For function names, ensure that you are only calling functions that accept the proper number of arguments, to avoid unexpected null arguments.

name: Function Call with Incorrectly Specified Arguments

metadata.Description: Once found, these issues are easy to fix. Use code inspection tools and relevant compiler features to identify potential violations. Pay special attention to code that is not likely to be exercised heavily during QA.

name: Function Call with Incorrectly Specified Arguments

metadata.Description: Make sure your API's are stable before you use them in production code.

name: Not Failing Securely ('Failing Open')

metadata.Description: Subdivide and allocate resources and components so that a failure in one part does not affect the entire product.

name: Unnecessary Complexity in Protection Mechanism (Not Using 'Economy of Mechanism')

metadata.Description: Avoid complex security mechanisms when simpler ones would meet requirements. Avoid complex data models, and unnecessarily complex operations. Adopt architectures that provide guarantees, simplify understanding through elegance and abstraction, and that can be implemented similarly. Modularize, isolate and do not trust complex code, and apply other secure programming principles on these modules (e.g., least privilege) to mitigate vulnerabilities.

name: Not Using Complete Mediation

metadata.Description: Invalidate cached privileges, file handles or descriptors, or other access credentials whenever identities, processes, policies, roles, capabilities or permissions change. Perform complete authentication checks before accepting, caching and reusing data, dynamic content and code (scripts). Avoid caching access control decisions as much as possible.

name: Not Using Complete Mediation

metadata.Description: Identify all possible code paths that might access sensitive resources. If possible, create and use a single interface that performs the access checks, and develop code standards that require use of this interface.

name: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled Key

metadata.Description: For each and every data access, ensure that the user has sufficient privilege to access the record that is being requested.

name: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled Key

metadata.Description: Make sure that the key that is used in the lookup of a specific user's record is not controllable externally by the user or that any tampering can be detected.

name: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled Key

metadata.Description: Use encryption in order to make it more difficult to guess other legitimate values of the key or associate a digital signature with the key so that the server can verify that there has been no tampering.

name: Weak Password Recovery Mechanism for Forgotten Password

metadata.Description: Make sure that all input supplied by the user to the password recovery mechanism is thoroughly filtered and validated.

name: Weak Password Recovery Mechanism for Forgotten Password

metadata.Description: Do not use standard weak security questions and use several security questions.

name: Weak Password Recovery Mechanism for Forgotten Password

metadata.Description: Make sure that there is throttling on the number of incorrect answers to a security question. Disable the password recovery functionality after a certain (small) number of incorrect guesses.

name: Weak Password Recovery Mechanism for Forgotten Password

metadata.Description: Require that the user properly answers the security question prior to resetting their password and sending the new password to the e-mail address of record.

name: Weak Password Recovery Mechanism for Forgotten Password

metadata.Description: Never allow the user to control what e-mail address the new password will be sent to in the password recovery mechanism.

name: Weak Password Recovery Mechanism for Forgotten Password

metadata.Description: Assign a new temporary password rather than revealing the original password.

name: Improper Restriction of Names for Files and Other Resources

metadata.Description: Do not allow users to control names of resources used on the server side.

name: Improper Restriction of Names for Files and Other Resources

metadata.Description: Perform allowlist input validation at entry points and also before consuming the resources. Reject bad file names rather than trying to cleanse them.

name: Improper Restriction of Names for Files and Other Resources

metadata.Description: Make sure that technologies consuming the resources are not vulnerable (e.g. buffer overflow, format string, etc.) in a way that would allow code execution if the name of the resource is malformed.

name: External Control of Critical State Data

metadata.Description: Understand all the potential locations that are accessible to attackers. For example, some programmers assume that cookies and hidden form fields cannot be modified by an attacker, or they may not consider that environment variables can be modified before a privileged program is invoked.

name: External Control of Critical State Data

metadata.Description:
Store state information and sensitive data on the server side only.
                  Ensure that the system definitively and unambiguously keeps track of its own state and user state and has rules defined for legitimate state transitions. Do not allow any application user to affect state directly in any way other than through legitimate actions leading to state transitions.
                  If information must be stored on the client, do not do so without encryption and integrity checking, or otherwise having a mechanism on the server side to catch tampering. Use a message authentication code (MAC) algorithm, such as Hash Message Authentication Code (HMAC) [REF-529]. Apply this against the state or sensitive data that you has to be exposed, which can guarantee the integrity of the data - i.e., that the data has not been modified. Ensure that a strong hash function is used (CWE-328).

name: External Control of Critical State Data

metadata.Description: Store state information on the server side only. Ensure that the system definitively and unambiguously keeps track of its own state and user state and has rules defined for legitimate state transitions. Do not allow any application user to affect state directly in any way other than through legitimate actions leading to state transitions.

name: External Control of Critical State Data

metadata.Description:
Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.
                  With a stateless protocol such as HTTP, use some frameworks can maintain the state for you.
                  Examples include ASP.NET View State and the OWASP ESAPI Session Management feature.
                  Be careful of language features that provide state support, since these might be provided as a convenience to the programmer and may not be considering security.

name: External Control of Critical State Data

metadata.Description: For any security checks that are performed on the client side, ensure that these checks are duplicated on the server side, in order to avoid CWE-602. Attackers can bypass the client-side checks by modifying values after the checks have been performed, or by changing the client to remove the client-side checks entirely. Then, these modified values would be submitted to the server.

name: External Control of Critical State Data

metadata.Description: When using PHP, configure the application so that it does not use register_globals. During implementation, develop the application so that it does not rely on this feature, but be wary of implementing a register_globals emulation that is subject to weaknesses such as CWE-95, CWE-621, and similar issues.

name: External Control of Critical State Data

metadata.Description: Use automated static analysis tools that target this type of weakness. Many modern techniques use data flow analysis to minimize the number of false positives. This is not a perfect solution, since 100% accuracy and coverage are not feasible.

name: External Control of Critical State Data

metadata.Description: Use dynamic tools and techniques that interact with the software using large test suites with many diverse inputs, such as fuzz testing (fuzzing), robustness testing, and fault injection. The software's operation may slow down, but it should not become unstable, crash, or generate incorrect results.

name: External Control of Critical State Data

metadata.Description: Use tools and techniques that require manual (human) analysis, such as penetration testing, threat modeling, and interactive tools that allow the tester to record and modify an active session. These may be more effective than strictly automated techniques. This is especially the case with weaknesses that are related to design and business rules.

name: Improper Neutralization of Data within XPath Expressions ('XPath Injection')

metadata.Description: Use parameterized XPath queries (e.g. using XQuery). This will help ensure separation between data plane and control plane.

name: Improper Neutralization of Data within XPath Expressions ('XPath Injection')

metadata.Description: Properly validate user input. Reject data where appropriate, filter where appropriate and escape where appropriate. Make sure input that will be used in XPath queries is safe in that context.

name: Improper Neutralization of HTTP Headers for Scripting Syntax

metadata.Description: Perform output validation in order to filter/escape/encode unsafe data that is being passed from the server in an HTTP response header.

name: Improper Neutralization of HTTP Headers for Scripting Syntax

metadata.Description: Disable script execution functionality in the clients' browser.

name: Overly Restrictive Account Lockout Mechanism

metadata.Description: Implement more intelligent password throttling mechanisms such as those which take IP address into account, in addition to the login name.

name: Overly Restrictive Account Lockout Mechanism

metadata.Description: Implement a lockout timeout that grows as the number of incorrect login attempts goes up, eventually resulting in a complete lockout.

name: Overly Restrictive Account Lockout Mechanism

metadata.Description: Consider alternatives to account lockout that would still be effective against password brute force attacks, such as presenting the user machine with a puzzle to solve (makes it do some computation).

name: Reliance on File Name or Extension of Externally-Supplied File

metadata.Description: Make decisions on the server side based on file content and not on file name or extension.

name: Use of Non-Canonical URL Paths for Authorization Decisions

metadata.Description: Make access control policy based on path information in canonical form. Use very restrictive regular expressions to validate that the path is in the expected form.

name: Use of Non-Canonical URL Paths for Authorization Decisions

metadata.Description: Reject all alternate path encodings that are not in the expected canonical form.

name: Incorrect Use of Privileged APIs

metadata.Description: Before calling privileged APIs, always ensure that the assumptions made by the privileged code hold true prior to making the call.

name: Incorrect Use of Privileged APIs

metadata.Description: Know architecture and implementation weaknesses of the privileged APIs and make sure to account for these weaknesses before calling the privileged APIs to ensure that they can be called safely.

name: Incorrect Use of Privileged APIs

metadata.Description: If privileged APIs make certain assumptions about data, context or state validity that are passed by the caller, the calling code must ensure that these assumptions have been validated prior to making the call.

name: Incorrect Use of Privileged APIs

metadata.Description: If privileged APIs do not shed their privilege prior to returning to the calling code, then calling code needs to shed these privileges immediately and safely right after the call to the privileged APIs. In particular, the calling code needs to ensure that a privileged thread of execution will never be returned to the user or made available to user-controlled processes.

name: Incorrect Use of Privileged APIs

metadata.Description: Only call privileged APIs from safe, consistent and expected state.

name: Incorrect Use of Privileged APIs

metadata.Description: Ensure that a failure or an error will not leave a system in a state where privileges are not properly shed and privilege escalation is possible (i.e. fail securely with regards to handling of privileges).

name: Reliance on Obfuscation or Encryption of Security-Relevant Inputs without Integrity Checking

metadata.Description: Protect important client controllable tokens/parameters for integrity using PKI methods (i.e. digital signatures) or other means, and checks for integrity on the server side.

name: Reliance on Obfuscation or Encryption of Security-Relevant Inputs without Integrity Checking

metadata.Description: Repeated requests from a particular user that include invalid values of tokens/parameters (those that should not be changed manually by users) should result in the user account lockout.

name: Reliance on Obfuscation or Encryption of Security-Relevant Inputs without Integrity Checking

metadata.Description: Client side tokens/parameters should not be such that it would be easy/predictable to guess another valid state.

name: Reliance on Obfuscation or Encryption of Security-Relevant Inputs without Integrity Checking

metadata.Description: Obfuscation should not be relied upon. If encryption is used, it needs to be properly applied (i.e. proven algorithm and implementation, use padding, use random initialization vector, user proper encryption mode). Even with proper encryption where the ciphertext does not leak information about the plaintext or reveal its structure, compromising integrity is possible (although less likely) without the provision of the integrity service.

name: Trusting HTTP Permission Methods on the Server Side

metadata.Description: Configure ACLs on the server side to ensure that proper level of access control is defined for each accessible resource representation.

name: Exposure of WSDL File Containing Sensitive Information

metadata.Description: Limit access to the WSDL file as much as possible. If services are provided only to a limited number of entities, it may be better to provide WSDL privately to each of these entities than to publish WSDL publicly.

name: Exposure of WSDL File Containing Sensitive Information

metadata.Description: Make sure that WSDL does not describe methods that should not be publicly accessible. Make sure to protect service methods that should not be publicly accessible with access controls.

name: Exposure of WSDL File Containing Sensitive Information

metadata.Description: Do not use method names in WSDL that might help an adversary guess names of private methods/resources used by the service.

name: Improper Neutralization of Data within XQuery Expressions ('XQuery Injection')

metadata.Description: Use parameterized queries. This will help ensure separation between data plane and control plane.

name: Improper Neutralization of Data within XQuery Expressions ('XQuery Injection')

metadata.Description: Properly validate user input. Reject data where appropriate, filter where appropriate and escape where appropriate. Make sure input that will be used in XQL queries is safe in that context.

name: Improper Isolation or Compartmentalization

metadata.Description: Break up privileges between different modules, objects, or entities. Minimize the interfaces between modules and require strong access control between them.

name: Reliance on a Single Factor in a Security Decision

metadata.Description: Use multiple simultaneous checks before granting access to critical operations or granting critical privileges. A weaker but helpful mitigation is to use several successive checks (multiple layers of security).

name: Reliance on a Single Factor in a Security Decision

metadata.Description: Use redundant access rules on different choke points (e.g., firewalls).

name: Insufficient Psychological Acceptability

metadata.Description: Where possible, perform human factors and usability studies to identify where your product's security mechanisms are difficult to use, and why.

name: Insufficient Psychological Acceptability

metadata.Description: Make the security mechanism as seamless as possible, while also providing the user with sufficient details when a security decision produces unexpected results.

name: Reliance on Security Through Obscurity

metadata.Description: Always consider whether knowledge of your code or design is sufficient to break it. Reverse engineering is a highly successful discipline, and financially feasible for motivated adversaries. Black-box techniques are established for binary analysis of executables that use obfuscation, runtime analysis of proprietary protocols, inferring file formats, and others.

name: Reliance on Security Through Obscurity

metadata.Description: When available, use publicly-vetted algorithms and procedures, as these are more likely to undergo more extensive security analysis and testing. This is especially the case with encryption and authentication.

name: Improper Synchronization

metadata.Description: Use industry standard APIs to synchronize your code.

name: Use of a Non-reentrant Function in a Concurrent Context

metadata.Description: Use reentrant functions if available.

name: Use of a Non-reentrant Function in a Concurrent Context

metadata.Description: Add synchronization to your non-reentrant function.

name: Use of a Non-reentrant Function in a Concurrent Context

metadata.Description: In Java, use the ReentrantLock Class.

name: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime

metadata.Description: Use Static analysis tools to check for unreleased resources.

name: Improper Initialization

metadata.Description:
Use a language that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.
                  For example, in Java, if the programmer does not explicitly initialize a variable, then the code could produce a compile-time error (if the variable is local) or automatically initialize the variable to the default value for the variable's type. In Perl, if explicit initialization is not performed, then a default value of undef is assigned, which is interpreted as 0, false, or an equivalent value depending on the context in which the variable is accessed.

name: Improper Initialization

metadata.Description: Identify all variables and data stores that receive information from external sources, and apply input validation to make sure that they are only initialized to expected values.

name: Improper Initialization

metadata.Description: Explicitly initialize all your variables and other data stores, either during declaration or just before the first usage.

name: Improper Initialization

metadata.Description: Pay close attention to complex conditionals that affect initialization, since some conditions might not perform the initialization.

name: Improper Initialization

metadata.Description: Avoid race conditions (CWE-362) during initialization routines.

name: Improper Initialization

metadata.Description: Run or compile your software with settings that generate warnings about uninitialized variables or data.

name: Improper Initialization

metadata.Description: Use automated static analysis tools that target this type of weakness. Many modern techniques use data flow analysis to minimize the number of false positives. This is not a perfect solution, since 100% accuracy and coverage are not feasible.

name: Operation on Resource in Wrong Phase of Lifetime

metadata.Description: Follow the resource's lifecycle from creation to release.

name: Improper Locking

metadata.Description: Use industry standard APIs to implement locking mechanism.

name: Uncontrolled Recursion

metadata.Description: Ensure an end condition will be reached under all logic conditions.  The end condition may include testing against the depth of recursion and exiting with an error if the recursion goes too deep. The complexity of the end condition contributes to the effectiveness of this action.

name: Uncontrolled Recursion

metadata.Description: Increase the stack size.

name: Use of Potentially Dangerous Function

metadata.Description: Identify a list of prohibited API functions and prohibit developers from using these functions, providing safer alternatives. In some cases, automatic code analysis tools or the compiler can be instructed to spot use of prohibited functions, such as the "banned.h" include file from Microsoft's SDL. [REF-554] [REF-7]

name: Incorrect Conversion between Numeric Types

metadata.Description: Avoid making conversion between numeric types. Always check for the allowed ranges.

name: Incorrect Calculation

metadata.Description: Understand your programming language's underlying representation and how it interacts with numeric calculation. Pay close attention to byte size discrepancies, precision, signed/unsigned distinctions, truncation, conversion and casting between types, "not-a-number" calculations, and how your language handles numbers that are too large or too small for its underlying representation.

name: Incorrect Calculation

metadata.Description: Perform input validation on any numeric input by ensuring that it is within the expected range. Enforce that the input meets both the minimum and maximum requirements for the expected range.

name: Incorrect Calculation

metadata.Description: Use the appropriate type for the desired action. For example, in C/C++, only use unsigned types for values that could never be negative, such as height, width, or other numbers related to quantity.

name: Incorrect Calculation

metadata.Description:
Use languages, libraries, or frameworks that make it easier to handle numbers without unexpected consequences.
                  Examples include safe integer handling packages such as SafeInt (C++) or IntegerLib (C or C++).

name: Incorrect Calculation

                  Examples include safe integer handling packages such as SafeInt (C++) or IntegerLib (C or C++).

name: Incorrect Calculation

metadata.Description: Examine compiler warnings closely and eliminate problems with potential security implications, such as signed / unsigned mismatch in memory operations, or use of uninitialized variables. Even if the weakness is rarely exploitable, a single failure may lead to the compromise of the entire system.

name: Incorrect Calculation

metadata.Description: Use automated static analysis tools that target this type of weakness. Many modern techniques use data flow analysis to minimize the number of false positives. This is not a perfect solution, since 100% accuracy and coverage are not feasible.

name: Incorrect Calculation

metadata.Description: Use dynamic tools and techniques that interact with the software using large test suites with many diverse inputs, such as fuzz testing (fuzzing), robustness testing, and fault injection. The software's operation may slow down, but it should not become unstable, crash, or generate incorrect results.

name: Function Call With Incorrect Order of Arguments

metadata.Description: Use the function, procedure, or routine as specified.

name: Function Call With Incorrect Order of Arguments

metadata.Description: Because this function call often produces incorrect behavior it will usually be detected during testing or normal operation of the software. During testing exercise all possible control paths will typically expose this weakness except in rare cases when the incorrect function call accidentally produces the correct results or if the provided argument type is very similar to the expected argument type.

name: Use of Multiple Resources with Duplicate Identifier

metadata.Description: Where possible, use unique identifiers. If non-unique identifiers are detected, then do not operate any resource with a non-unique identifier and report the error appropriately.

name: Incorrect Ownership Assignment

metadata.Description: Periodically review the privileges and their owners.

name: Incorrect Ownership Assignment

name: Improper Adherence to Coding Standards
